comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: The lamps on the bridge are still there but the globes have changed a number of times over the years.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: It was 1.10pm when this was taken.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: The very lovely Jayne Shrimpton just replied to me on Twitter with her dating input on this one: "Ok ladies hat styles c.1906-10, sleeve styles c.1904-09, so likely date of photo c.1906-09"
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Google Streetview.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content:
I've examined the photos and I can see no sign of the Boat house I think it should be in this photo on the far bank to the right of the bridge. It is possible that it is hiden by that tree but it was built in 1900, architect W J Given of Coleraine.

You can see the boat house from the position this photo must have been taken at least as close as street view can get. I beleive the photo was taken from the first floor of the clothworkers building.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think the boat house would be out of shot to the right, at the far end of Hanover Gardens.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] In Street view it looks futher away than it is as it was taken with a wide angle lens. If you go back a couple of paces in street view from your link you can see the boat house and the wall where the people are sitting in the photo.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Anyone with a few minutes to spare? Got in great info on another Hogan photo that we had dated as November 1920, but turned out to be 14 October 1920. I'm trying to pinpoint exact location on the quays in Dublin (and I'm supposed to be doing something else right now - a lot less fun, but don't tell on me). Virtual choccie in it for whoever gets us a location and/or real gratitude!
